claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.
explanation: Scatter plots comparing pre- and post-vaccination proportions of subjects with ≥4-fold reduced hemagglutination inhibition (HI) titers to cell-propagated influenza vaccine viruses, stratified by viral strain (A(H3N2), A(H1N1)pdm09, B/VIC, B/YAM), age group (18–44 and 45–64 years), and vaccine type (egg-based IIV4-Fluzone, cell-based ccIIV4, and recombinant RIV4, in various prime/boost combinations). Evidence: Recipients of egg-based IIV4-Fluzone showed a significantly higher proportion of ≥4-fold reduced HI titers against cell-derived A(H1N1)pdm09 (p=0.02) and B/VIC (p=0.03) viruses compared with cell-based vaccines. The figure supports the claim by demonstrating that egg-based vaccine recipients had diminished serologic responses to cell-propagated virus strains, consistent with egg-adapted mutations during production that may reduce vaccine effectiveness. Note: Immunologic titers are surrogates and the figure does not directly display genetic sequence mutations during vaccine production.
